title: 3564 Talthybius
text:
3564 Talthybius is a large <a href="Jupiter%20trojan">Jupiter trojan</a> from the <a href="Greek%20camp">Greek camp</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 15 October 1985, by American astronomer <a href="Edward%20Bowell">Edward Bowell</a> at the <a href="Anderson%20Mesa%20Station">Anderson Mesa Station</a> near Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States. The dark <a href="D-type%20asteroid">D-type asteroid</a> belongs to the <a href="%23Largest%20Jupiter%20trojans">50 largest Jupiter trojans</a> and has a relatively long <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of 40.59 hours. It was named after the Greek hero <a href="Talthybius">Talthybius</a>, who was a herald during the <a href="Trojan%20War">Trojan War</a>.
Orbit and classification.
"Talthybius" is a dark Jovian <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> orbiting in the leading Greek camp at Jupiter's <a href="Lagrangian%20point">Lagrangian point</a>, 60<a href="degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> ahead its orbit in a <a href="Orbital%20resonance">1:1 resonance</a> "(see <a href="Trojans%20in%20astronomy">Trojans in astronomy</a>)". It is also a non-<a href="Asteroid%20family">family</a> asteroid in the <a href="background%20asteroid">Jovian background population</a>.
It orbits the Sun at a distance of 5.0–5.4 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 11 years and 10 months (4,334 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 5.2 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.04 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 16<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> at <a href="Palomar%20Observatory">Palomar Observatory</a> in December 1950, almost 35 years prior to its official discovery observation at Anderson Mesa.
Physical characteristics.
In the <a href="Sloan%20Digital%20Sky%20Survey">SDSS</a>-based taxonomy, "Talthybius" is dark <a href="D-type%20asteroid">D-type asteroid</a>. <a href="Pan-STARRS">Pan-STARRS</a>'s survey also characterized it as a D-type, while the "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" (CALL) assumed it to be of a carbonaceous <a href="C-type%20asteroid">C-type</a> composition.
Rotation period.
In June 1994, a rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Talthybius" was obtained by <a href="Stefano%20Mottola">Stefano Mottola</a> and Anders Erikson using the <a href="Bochum%200.61-metre%20Telescope">Bochum 0.61-metre Telescope</a> at <a href="La%20Silla%20Observatory">La Silla Observatory</a> in Chile. Lightcurve analysis gave a <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of 40.59 hours with a brightness variation of 0.38 <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a> ().
<a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">Photometric</a> observations by <a href="Robert%20D.%20Stephens">Robert Stephen</a> at the Goat Mountain Astronomical Research Station in November 2009 and at the <a href="Center%20for%20Solar%20System%20Studies">Center for Solar System Studies</a> in February 2015, gave two concurring periods of 40.40 and 40.44 hours with a corresponding amplitude of 0.31 and 0.38 ().
While not being a <a href="List%20of%20slow%20rotators%20%28minor%20planets%29">slow rotator</a>, "Talthybius"es period is significantly longer than that of most larger Jupiter trojans, which have a spin rate of typically 10 hours.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the surveys carried out by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite <a href="IRAS">IRAS</a>, the Japanese <a href="Akari%20%28satellite%29">Akari satellite</a> and the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, "Talthybius" measures between 68.92 and 74.11 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> between 0.062 and 0.093. CALL derives an albedo of 0.0654 and a diameter of 68.53 kilometers based on an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 9.4.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after the Greek hero <a href="Talthybius">Talthybius</a> from <a href="Greek%20mythology">Greek mythology</a>, who was the chief <a href="herald">herald</a> during the <a href="Trojan%20War">Trojan War</a>. The official naming citation was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 5 November 1987 ().
